fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-11158].
  {panel}

Jira supports "Reporter" as a role that it maintains. 
Also "Assignee". 
It would be nice to add "Project Lead" to that list as well.

Role-names should be available in every name picker, and in every situation in which I can select a name/person. 
Conditions and post functions should support the use of all roles.
I should be able to assign to or restrict to (or whatever) to the Reporter, the Project Lead, the current Assignee, etc.

I am filing a separate bug that requests Jira saving he name of the person that caused each issue transition.
Those "roles" should be supported, too, as above.
fields.summary: Make "Project Lead" a role

fields.description:
In emails that get sent out when the assignee is changed back to unassigned, the following html appears in the email:
The following ticket has been re-assigned.

Assignee: $18n.getText("common.concepts.unassigned")

To reproduce: 1. Create a new issue. 2. Assign the issue to somebody (you'll receive an email with the proper assignee listed) 3. Unassign the issue. 4. You'll now receive an email with the above html.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-11153].
  {panel}

Now in Jira there is only project-version abstract levels.
I think it would be great to have one more level: "product"

In my company there is much more products in project then one.
E.g User Manual, test plan, and much more 
Often project is composed with many software modules
Each has own version, users wokring on it, leaders and so on...

Using components is not enough.
And creating new project for every product is very strange (and takes a lot of time).
Maybe if group of project has all project properties, end each project could inherit it....

Is there any chance to implement it?

Best regards
Pawel
fields.summary: "Product" abstract level

fields.description:
In Admin -> General Configuration, there is an *External password management* flag which we recommend people turn on when using [LDAP|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/ldap.html]. In this case, when new users are created, it makes no sense to send the password in the email notification, since the password is unused (the LDAP password takes precedence). In fact, if users are self-registering and may enter their LDAP password, this is a security risk, as we don't want valid passwords going over unencrypted email.

For people using JIRA currently, passwords in signup emails can be prevented by editing:

atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/templates/email/text/includes/userdetails.vm
fields.summary: Don't send passwords in emails when External password/user management enabled

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-11142].
  {panel}

At present there's no way to create / modify notification schemes for projects. 

(At Codehaus, we're trying to automate project creation completely; to do so we need to create a custom notification scheme for each project that emails the appropriate developer list).

It would be useful if there was a way to manipulate notification schemes via the SOAP api (we don't use XML-RPC - but I realise that you automatically target both).



In any API changes, please consider whether the API will be fast when dealing with large JIRA instances - some parts of the remote API are useless when dealing with our instance due to the large number of users / groups (eg. getProjects).


Thanks,

Ben
fields.summary: Allow creation/modification of notification schemes

fields.description:
Currently, Jira does not allow a user (administrator) to change a project key, while editing a project. A work-around is described here: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=12703 . As it is noted, this is very inconvenient operation. I suggest to support project key alteration within JIRA's user interface. This will eliminate all possible errors, humans can make during manual patching of XML backup and folders.

A project key is very likely to be changed synchronously with the project renaming. It would be strange, if a project (say, software project) changes its name, but the key for it still contains an old prefix.

*Workaround*

Create a new project, and bulk move all the issues into the new project. This way, they will still be able to be referenced by their old key and their new key.
fields.summary: An ability to edit a project key is missing

fields.description: I have a need to set up filters (for clients) _before_ any issues are actually logged. However, if I try to add filter order, I am told "You cannot browse any issues at the moment. You need to be able to browse issues to customise issue navigator.". What I need to do is set up th column ordering even without issues. My workaround is I have to create dummy issues in order to add filter columns and do ordering. Then delete the issues. or, I have to edit the filter to include issues I don't want, to do that, then edit the filter to exclude those issues again. Either way, it would be helpful if JIRA could allow me to do that without either of those workarounds.
fields.summary: Allow setting of column order/sort with no issues in result set

fields.description:
The Create Issue link fails when visited directly by a user who is not logged in, showing "You have not selected a valid project to create an issue in". The page should explain that the user must login. 

Ideally, the create issue display would either redirect to the login page and signup pages, or embed a login username and password with signup link directly. Fixing this will allow users to create support tickets with less overhead.

The Operations menu (or panel) shown on the left-hand edge of the issue screens must be custimizable in several ways. For each operation (Assign, Edit, Clone, etc) we must have a possibility to set its visibility: 1) in the global scope, 2) per user group, 3) per status.

The related issue JRA-8497 exists already, but it is about Clone operation only.
fields.summary: A flexible customization of the Operations menu is required

fields.description:
This issue is an open petition to Atlassian.  We believe that JIRA is missing a number of features that prevent it from being truly enterprise-ready.  We are not asking to have these issues addressed immediately, but we do believe that our maintenance agreement for JIRA enterprise entitles us to some consideration of how these issues fit into the JIRA roadmap.

If you are an enterprise customer, please consider not only voting for this issue but also comment to indicate that you are signing this petition.  

Also feel free to link in other issues that I have been missed.  Any issues that I link will meet the following criteria:
# Major functionality change, either an improvement or a new feature.
# Likely to be high priority for a customer of JIRA enterprise.
# Identified for quite some time (most over a year, often multiple years).
# Not scheduled for any version of JIRA.
# May have comments about bumping it back from release to release.
# Typically has a high number of votes and watchers.

For more details on why I felt it necessary to create this issue, consider reading my <RANT> on [JRA-1549|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-1549#action_64375].
fields.summary: JIRA 4.0 Enterprise Requirements

fields.description:
Often we have support requests where people ask 'how do I log out', or 'where is the view profile link'.  This is most often because they configure the top text and top background colors to be the same.

We should print a warning when this happens.
fields.summary: Warn users when the top background colour is the same as top text colour

fields.description:
Can you please describe in detail how to perform Step (10):

(1) You have a JIRA database with (eg) 2,250 items
(2) Project-A has 950 items out of the 2,250 items
(3) Project-A has finished so you decide to backup the 950 items.
(4) You also decide to reduce the 2,250 item JIRA database by 950 by deleteing the 950 items. 
(5) You specify a filter that shows all 950 items that belong to Project-A.
(6) You create an XML extract of these 950 items by clicking on the button for XML extracts in JIRA.
(7) You then save the XML extract onto your hard drive (somewhere).
(8) You perform a bulk delete of all 950 items that belong to Project-A.
(9) Three months later, there is a requirement to review Project-A JIRA items.
(10) Can you please explain how I perform an XML import activity from within JIRA using the XML extract file fome Step (7).

I need to know how to perform Step (10). Can you please help.

fields.description:
Since JIRA offers the possibility to assign custom fields to project-specific contexts, one would expect only those fields (plus the fields in a global context) to be shown as filter options on the "Find issues" page. 
When working with a large number of projects (most of them with very specific fields), defining filters is nearly impossible for users who have to choose from the set of *all* fields, some of them with similar names and totally different meanings (maybe even with different data types).
As the permissions for most of our users only allow them to browse through a single project (or a small set of projects), showing fields from other contexts does not make any sense.
On the other hand, JIRA's Import Wizard does only show fields in a global or project context when assigning to existing fields (when importing into an existing project).
I would expect this from all project specific features in JIRA.
fields.summary: Custom Field Configuration Contexts should limit field visibility when configuring filters and the navigator

A lot of the branding in Jira - even the Enterprise version - is global to the application.  Like yourselves with the branding differences between Jira (blue) and Confluence (green), We have significant branding at product level, rather than company level.

Our client base know the application branding rather than the company branding, so when clients / users login to Jira, I need them to see the application-specific colour palette (and logo) in the display.

Currently the only way I can see this being possible is to have two completely separate installs of Jira, so the "global" branding can be application-specific.

I examined the underlying mark-up Jira generates to see if I could simply swap out the CSS file used, via a webserver filter, but it seems  that you are hard-coding the selected colour palette directly into the HTML, rather than using CSS (!).  So that's not a starter.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-11074].
  {panel}

JIRA's mail service (which processes incoming mails) should have the ability to ignore mail bounces, so that they do not result in new issues (and possible mail loops).

Of the jira-user bounces I receive:
 - 75% have a *Content-Type: multipart/report* header
 - 17% are from *mailer-daemon@'
 - 8% are from majordomo, and the subject starts with "BOUNCE" (most people wouldn't get these).

Of bounces to personal mail, almost 100% are covered by the first two of these heuristics.

Almost none of these bounces have the Precedence: bulk header, which we [added a check for|JRA-8863] in an attempt to avoid bounces.

So without going overboard and implementing a full mail filter in JIRA, I think we could identify most mail bounces with 2 simple hardcoded rules.
fields.summary: Mail service should ignore obvious mail bounces

fields.description:
There is no reasonably priced Test Case Management tool on the market - there is a big oportunity here to provide an obvious add on to Jira.
Things like Mercury Test Director are enormously expesive when compared to Jira, and really, they dont do that much.

I work in a medium sized software firm - about 60 employees. We have a dedicated testing team, of about 6-10 people. They mostly do manual functional testing, with detailed test cases which are derived from Use Cases and other specs.

A couple of years ago we went down the path of writing our own test case management tool, because there was nothing reasonable in the market, either commercial or open source. We are now looking at redeveloping the tool, as it has maintainence problems. There is still nothing in the market.

Test case management has an obvious integration with defect/issue management, so any tool would need to integrate with Jira.
Much better still would be if it was within Jira. It is the same users, projects, and generally there is a One-To-Many between test case and defect.

There are three parts to this - creating test cases, executing them, and reporting on them.

Its pretty simple really - A project has many test cases, which may be linked to a Use Case (Issue type?) and maybe a version.
Each test case has mutiple steps, which have an index and a description, plus some other minor fields.
You need a nice effecient interface to create these steps.
Each test case can have many runs, or executions.
When running a test case, a tester is presented with another UI that efficiently allows them to work through the steps of the test case, and mark each step as completed, or not. Where a step cannot be completed a defect may be created, which is automatically linked to the the run.
The other crucial thing is a set of reports that allows a project manager or test manager to see how many and which tests are passing, how many runs have been done, etc.

As I said, we are currently looking at redeveloping our test case tool, but would much rather use an externally developed product - and an add on to Jira would be the ideal solution. We could possibly help with the detailed requirements of such an addition to Jira. Please let me know if there is any interest.

Jon Nermut
Project Manager
Dytech Solutions
Hobart
03 6235 2222
fields.summary: Test Case Management

I have, in my email template: {noformat} #if ($issue.getCustomFieldValue("customfield_10103")) $stringUtils.leftPad($issue.getCustomField("customfield_10103").name, $padSize): $issue.getCustomFieldValue("customfield_10103") #end {noformat} which correctly displays the domain of reporter (as shown). Problem is, the field is limited in context to 2 support projects, and now it is showing up on all internal mail notifications - i.e. it is showing up for projects for which this custom field does not have it defined in the context. I realize this may be a tooklit issue (also reported at http://developer.atlassian.com/jira/browse/JTOOL-7), but if I could get a workaround (like an if statement to only show it if the project is one of 2 support projects), I would appreciate it.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-11054].
  {panel}

There is no easy way for someone commenting on an issue through the web UI to see precisely who will see that comment via email once the 'Add' button is pressed. The 'Viewable by' combo box gives some indication, but one must know what permissions and notification schemes are applied, in combination with watchers. 

The same problem also exists when responding to an email from JIRA - there is no indication of who has received a copy of the message nor is there indication of who (other than the instigator of the comment/action) would also see any response.

Suggestions:

1) Whenever an action editor (comment, work log, resolution, etc.) is invoked through the web UI, JIRA should display a list  of users who will receive an email as a result of completing the action. 

2) Make list of email targets (full user names) for an issue available to Velocity templates so that names of all recipients can be prepended to message bodies.
fields.summary: Display a list of users who will receive email as a result of executing an action

fields.description: The AddVersion jelly tag has no attribute to allow the id of the created entity to be set in the Jelly context. Other tags have this. This would enable the use of the created version in other tags which reference it by id.
fields.summary: Make AddVersion provide the created version id similar to other tags.
MailFetcherService holds on to memory for each message until end of service run

fields.description:
The Filter/search options should include Project Category. By this way, it would be possible to form and save Category-based filters.
Example of headache:
70 development projects.
All filters (a lot) include development projects but not the others.
If somehow, a new project or a new component (since components can not be versionned) based project created, it is necessary to edit all saved filters; otherwise the new project is out of scope of previously created filters.

fields.description:

fields.description:
Can we have the ability when we are filtering to be able to block out certain criteria.

For example on our components we may want to do a search on everything that isn't rasied by a particular person or everything that is not a particular status.
fields.summary: Can we add the functionality to block out certain criteria when searching

fields.description:
Ok - here's the problem:
{code}
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.caucho.server.http.DispatchRequest.getContextPath(DispatchRequest.java:173)
	at com.atlassian.jira.plugin.JiraResourcedModuleDescriptor.getDefaultVelocityParams(JiraResourcedModuleDescriptor.java:217)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.component.issuesummary.IssueSummaryWebComponent.getDefaultParams(IssueSummaryWebComponent.java:71)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.component.issuesummary.IssueSummaryWebComponent.getHtml(IssueSummaryWebComponent.java:66)
	at _decorators._issuesummary__jsp._jspService(_issuesummary__jsp.java:1583)
{code}

In Resin, it uses a new request for each 'include' that it does.  JSP include, using a requestwrapper etc.  In JIRA's ServletRequestDispatcher (webwork implementation), we capture the Request in a Thread Local, and use it later on in the request.  We also do the same with the action context.

After each request has completed, it gets returned to the pool, and all of its internal state cleared.

The problem that has been introduced with the new decorator is that in the decorator gets the request out of the Thread Local (ActionContext.getRequest()): {{JiraResourcedModuleDescriptor.getDefaultVelocityParams()}}.  However, as this request has been released back into the pool, the request.getContextPath() has been cleared, which throws the NullPointerException.

The solution is for our templates to not depend on the HttpServletRequest object, but instead see what we use from it, and provide that to the velocity context instead.  A quick search shows that the request object isn't used in that many places (at least inside JIRA):
{code}
for i in `find . -name *.vm` ; do grep "\$req" $i | grep -v "\$req.getContextPath()" | grep -v "\$req.contextPath" ; done;
{code}

Mostly we just use the contextPath, and we could find a better variable name for that.
fields.summary: Resin 2.1.17 throws NullPointerException on View Issue
Support JNDI definition of POP and IMAP servers

fields.description:
Mail Handler has an inefficient way of creating attachments from MimeParts.
This caused excess CPU usage and ran for an excessively long time.

See related issue for memory problems.
fields.summary: Fix MailHandler attachment code - CPU inefficient

fields.description:
If JIRA is set up to use SQL Server, then multi-byte characters (eg. Russian) are not stored correctly in some fields.

This is because JIRA uses the SQL Server {{TEXT}} data type for issue description, environment, issue comments, unlimited text custom fields and workflows. Instead, we should be using {{NTEXT}} for these, to allow Unicode characters to be stored.
fields.summary: Multi-byte characters not stored properly in description, comments when using SQL Server

fields.description: In managing a portal, I have the ability to create a description of each portal page. But it doesn't seem to be displayed anywhere. Although each portal is shown as a tab on the dashboard, the description is not shown when hovering over the portal link. That would be a helpful improvement.
fields.summary: Show portlet description as tooltip

fields.description:
The time element of the Date Time picker always opens as 12:00 am whatever time was initially in the field. 

All our settings are for a 24 hour clock - the Date Time picker uses a 12 hour clock:
  Time Format	HH:mm	14:54
  Day Format	yyyy-MM-dd	2006-09-04
  Complete Date/Time Format	yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm	2006-09-04 14:54
  Day/Month/Year Format	yyyy-MM-dd	2006-09-04
  Date Picker Format (javascript format)	yyyy-MM-dd (%Y-%m-%d)	2006-09-04
  Date Time Picker Format (javascript format)	yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm (%Y-%m-%d %R)	2006-09-04 14:54

When changing the time with the Date Time picker, the time element always returns "%R" instead of the selected time.

The time can however be directly overtyped in the field so problem not blocking.
fields.summary: Date Time Picker: time element returns the javascript format code (%R).
